DOC.HEAD: Florida Comptroller Takes Action To Remove Paul As CenTrust Chairman
Eds: SUBS 3rd graf with 2 grafs of CenTrust comment.
DOC.TEXT: State Comptroller Gerald Lewis today began legal action to remove David L. Paul as chairman of CenTrust Bank of Miami, claiming Paul has used Florida's largest savings and loan to support his ``opulent lifestyle.'' Lewis filed an administrative complaint that seeks removal of Paul as chairman of the thrift. Paul has 21 days to either contest the complaint through a state hearing or comply with it. CenTrust said it would oppose efforts to oust Paul and called Lewis' action was self-serving. ``This campaign is clearly aimed at generating favorable publicity for the comptroller and supporting his own re-election campaign whatever the cost to CenTrust, its shareholders and its customers,'' the company said in a statement. The complaint charged that Paul used CenTrust employees to perform personal services, charged the savings and loan for thousands of dollars in personal bills and engaged in other questionable financial transactions. ``Paul maintained an opulent lifestyle largely at the expense of the association, and generally treated a federally insured financial institution and public company as it if were his own public piggy bank,'' Lewis said in the complaint. Paul's actions were unsound and unsafe business practices that violated his duty as an officer of a financial institution, the complaint charged. The complaint was filed 11 days after federal regulators, also citing CenTrust's lavish spending practices, ordered the institution to stop squandering its assets on fine art, sailboats, excessive executive salaries and other personal expenses. Terence McElroy, spokesman for the comptroller's office, said the action today was highly unusual. ``But it's a fairly unusual institution,'' McElroy said. The complaint questioned Paul's $4.8 million in salary between January 1988 and September of this year during a time when the thrift suffered operating losses of $76 million before taxes. CenTrust also bought some $30 million in art in 1988 without Lewis' approval, spent thousands of dollars on executives' hotels bills and used high-prices limousines to ferry the thrift's officers around Miami, the complaint charged. The complaint also noted that $150,000 in CenTrust assets, including security equipment, video cameras, office supplies, telephones and air conditioners, were kept at Paul's home on La Gorce Island in Miami. When federal regulators made their charges earlier this month, Paul issued a statement saying he had turned around a previously insolvent thrift and reduced its losses. ``We have achieved that without one penny of federal assistance while investing millions of dollars in developing a first-rate institution with the financial strength in place to meet the need of our customers,'' Paul said at the time.
